So much more refreshing to me than the people closer to my age like Sharpton,  West and Dyson. 
You are much appreciated by me.

author: @satyasyasatyasya5746
text: when you've had nothing for so long, when you've faked it to make it, when everything and everyone around you says that only glitter and gold maketh the man, opulance and the aesthetics of power becomes another drug to keep folk in line. the house always wins.

author: @joceliterary
text: One of the best, most timely Olay & Friends episodes YET!

author: @GoodnWise
text: The Bill Cosby Show?  Uh. No.  Class divisions within the Black community are as old as the division between the field slaves and the house slave.  Where did WEB DuBois‚Äô Talented Tenth theory come from?  The Harlem Renaissance?  What about George Jefferson in the 70s?  The Evans family interacted with Black middle class people.

replies.author: @tacrewgirl
replies.text:
Yes, Black class divisions always existed in the US. The Cosby Show just brought it to the mainstream - a Black upperclass family that went to an HBCU. A Different World and the Hillman experience with Black people everywhere in a college environment had a huge impact on a generation of Black folk. And they discussed some class issues at Hillman within the student body. 

It was great marketing and symbolism in many ways.

replies.author: @antcantcook960
replies.text: They‚Äôre so naive.

author: @MamaShidah
text: I appreciate these conversations so much! The nuance brings me so much hope lol

replies.author: @olurinatti
replies.text: Thank you so much!

author: @ritajacobs1668
text: I would also note that the Black middle class is not a monolith. My parents had college degrees when I was born BUT, financially, my family was a lower middle class family of four.

author: @amberwingtundrawing776
text: The contradiction of progress in politics is that a person most likely wont be elected if they want genuine change to occur

author: @TheScholarofSqualor
text: Just got to the part where y'all mention The Body Politic and one of my best friends was one of the primary people behind it being filmed. It brought a big smile to my face hearing this film get recognized here as something showing good representation!!

author: @iamchrisvolpe
text: What an amazing ensemble of people. And Leah is so correct about how segregated nyc is bc as someone who grew up in Whitestone, Queens - I had that same realization in JHS when I went to live with my mom in Flushing and transferred Junior High Schools to RFK, then AGAIN when I went to Brooklyn Tech for HS. It‚Äôs absolutely ridiculous how shocked you are in those developmental moments bc I played soccer with a diverse group of kids but school wise, my elementary school was 90%+ white.

replies.author: @iamchrisvolpe
replies.text: And justice for KRJ!

author: @Quonjack
text: Wow!! Thanks for this impactful conversation! Especially a person who lives and loves Baltimore!! I‚Äôm literally the only progressive person in my black ass friend group/ family. Either they are too busy to care, too financially stable to care or just selfish (that‚Äôs not how I live). It‚Äôs draining.

author: @elaryn.new.22
text: Love this heat for Mayor Parker! I organize in Philly and she does a lot of relating to people because she's funny. But then she will turn around and move money away from essential services and sell Philly to billionaires (i.e., green-lighting the arena that will destroy Chinatown and other communities). My grandma, who has lived in Philly for 30 years, was in support of her but I spent time pointing out all of the issues that affect her and our community that the Mayor is making worse. She now sees these things, so I agree about the education portion.

replies.author: @elaryn.new.22
replies.text: Also Nic O'Rourke is the real deal!! For anyone interested in Philly politics definitely check him out.

replies.author: @kbt-143
replies.text: Yes!!! Parker has made so many policy WTFs since voted in (and I voted for her).

author: @tacrewgirl
text:
38:20 - "We always say Black people are not a monolith but we're always trying to decide on a monolithic representation." - bars by Olay


46:50 - "We have unproductive, not even unrealistic, conversations with people involved in this work." - FACTS

Facts, Jamal Bowman and Cori Bush got more popular once they were pushed out. 
Everyone on this panel had great insight. I wish everyone would watch this. Just because you don't agree with someone doesn't mean you don't do your job in politics.

"Harm reduction" and "seeing realistic expectations" were the phrases of the day.

author: @TanisshaHarrell
text:
As a Gen X‚Äôr child of the Civil Rights (post). I need more conversations like one. I learned so much and was educated aka school house rock ish. I live in So. California and I agree with much that was shared especially around working class as former Union employee  I learned and witnessed the deals before the deal if you know what I mean. 
I know this sounds naive but I wish the to run for any office did not require so much money b/c I have seen this is where values of candidates has the potential to cause misalignment between voters and what a candidate stands for. It‚Äôs the getting the seat of power and then once there well trying to maintain that seat where I have witnessed a lot of harm to the community. I need a part two please and thank you. Beautiful Black peoples having beautiful conversations appreciate y‚Äôall.

replies.author: @wyattteague6508
replies.text: Everyone makes mistakes, not everyone takes accountability. I can‚Äôt accept your apology on Chenjerai‚Äôs behalf, but I want to encourage you to learn from it without overindulging in self-blame. You do good work.

author: @ebsmith29
text: Consider this about Atlanta.  The political power structure is Black.  The real power structure in the city is not.  Sure, there were set asides or affirmative action for  minority contractors or city contracts for Black contractors-starting especially with Maynard Jackson.  However, the real power structure often gets what they want, or it looks like that to me.  We should remember the "Golden" rule:  He (or she) who has the gold makes the rules.  It should be safe to say that Atlanta is not the only city that has that situation.

replies.author: @ebsmith29
replies.text:
In 1990 Atlanta was about 67% Black.  It is now about 53-54% Black or less.

On organizing we should listen to the words of the late Kevin Alexander Gray.  He led Jesse Jackson's presidential campaign in South Carolina.  Mr. Gray talked about the importance of organizing.

author: @Peridot-banana
text: These panels are absolutely essential. I wish everyone could receive the kind of wisdom we are hearing here, from strategic leaders who are actually doing the work to invest in building power, not clout, not vibes, not having ‚Äòclean hands‚Äô symbolically. It‚Äôs absolutely sanity-restoring to be able to learn from the kinds of people you‚Äôve had on lately, and helps me to redirect my energy towards what can actually have an impact (vs. arguing with wrong people on the internet)‚Ä¶ thank you.

text: I appreciate everyone's points about practicality, the importance of building popular support and thereby leverage to actually accomplish good things. Major holdback in leftist spaces, discussion, etc.

author: @Thtbrwngene7
text: Someone on the panel mentioned how someone being from a neighborhood and not having any empathy for the people there and the people that they grew up with compared to someone that isn‚Äôt  from that place but still has empathy for them is very interesting. That take reminds me of Marion Barry and Muriel Bowser. Barry was from the south but was known for doing so much for the Black middle class and the natives as a whole in DC. Compared to Muriel Bowser who is a DC native but her work has been questioned in the past and as of now. That was a very intriguing thought.

author: @kbt-143
text: Whew thank yall. I been struggling with my hatred of Cherelle Parker and I feel alone in that üòÇ

author: @jagger2313
text: Thank you for this discussion. Seriously, this expresses so many reasons why I have difficulty involving myself in modern leftist movements that do come off uninformed and unhelpful.

author: @relaxlibrary4249
text: I think we can elect progressives, but with the idea of setting the table. We have to understand that one person or a small group of people can't undo everything in one term or even two. We have to set the stage for more players to make progressive changes over time. That way, we can hold them accountable for milestone changes that will lead overall progressive change.

author: @savagetwin52
text:
Olay, I totally enjoy the conversation. Ya'll are so brilliant and wise. I was born and raised in Harlem, am a babyboomer and I'm so filled. You all may be millennials and Genz. But you really have the minds of the boomers from the days of glorious revolution fighting against injustice. I've been living in Co-City for 43 years, just in time for the beginning of white flight. The person who has an Auntie a DC-37 retiree, if she hasn't already, join The Organization of NYC Public Service Retirees. She will learn about the traitorous unions. And DC37 and the UFT have messed up the money for the working force and see that privatizing our Medicare will benefit them. So they tried to sell us old people out. But most of us are boomers and took the city to court and won, and won and won, got taken to Appellate Court and kept on winning. But we still fighting. So make sure she research the organization on YouTube and website.

BTW, ya'll done raised up my spirit. It's still there, but caught in a sh*t hole body. I may not walk well, but can still learn and fight in different ways. I have seen Harlem being sold out years before Clinton was president by some of our black leaders, some of whom were depicted in Regina King's movie, "Shirley". Re: NYCHA...corrupt as hell, Adams....one term mayor full of himself. He was a republican before seeking office as Brooklyn Boro Prez. But knew he didn't stand a chance to win. So, he registered as a Democrat, but only in name. I voted for Maya Wiley in that primary still have my campaign hat. She would have won too, except she was going to "dismiss" the next graduating class of NYPD. 

So, once again, I say good night. Yes I'm a member and have twin sis. Called us The Savage Twins well into our senior years.üòÖ

author: @galhas537
text: Wonder if "negativity" includes also criticism cause if it is than it's a problem. And this is along with the lack of the necessary real just criticism- beyond the one against the system -towards the politicians themselves. You seem to prefer to find excuses to their underperformence. If you dont make the right distinction btw system and individuals (even if they're part if opressed community),  it will not get things better except ensuring a safe warm feeling

author: @gee8419
text: This is a great conversation. I‚Äôm hoping to canvass with DSA for Mayor in 2025. This is helpful context for door knocking.

author: @jinmushui1soul
text: You always bring an interesting conversation, that's for sure. I appreciate the question about "theory of change" because while I still don't agree with most of y'all, it does help me articulate my own theory of change, from both my own experience in movement work and studying both domestic and international movement history, is the threat of ungovernability. Now this can take many forms, but is ultimately always orthogonal to existing political or economic structures. So I'm not deeply invested in electoral politics, even in a local level (though understand why people are), but will always support direct action and grassroots organizing. And I feel that some lack of understanding from progressive officials. Now not every critique is meaningful, but I do think if you're going to work within the system, you do have to accept that critique is how you are held accountable to your purported radical ideals.

author: @ZaNeCuDdEr
text:
i thnk one of our weeknesses is overestimating the right...its not that they're good with messaging  full stop...its more of due to they're not a challenge to the current system compared to a leftists(plus being paid by billionaires helps) so they seem more "organized"...and unfortunately the left doesn't have that same apparatus so its more the deck was always staked in the rights favor thus things they say is considered permissible....like them with immigration and accusing them of eating pets..compared to the left who are VERY restrained due to the lack of  options to combat the rightwing or for their beliefs in general (mostly due to the dems and republicans being bipartisan on restricting the left or moderately progressive in general) 
..that being said the left dose need a sort of leader(s) because its leaderless movement has left it rudderless and opens the door for grifting in the movement   for example the BLM ORG acting like it was the movement and end up taking money

author: @internetuser7156
text: In response to Devin's comment, as a case worker, I don't necessarily want to be the one who responds to some of the cases I see. I'm not allowed to have any way to protect myself and sometimes being a black woman who understands and identifies with my community isn't enough.

author: @nicholasparks330
text:
What annoys me about ‚Äúwyte supremecy‚Äù dialog is the lack of understanding of how hegemonic systems work. Yes, the current hegemonic system is wyte in origin and wyte centered. However, the Western Democratic Capitalist hegemony operates a certain way and it doesn't matter who the cops/mayor/governors background may be. You can‚Äôt challenge how the system works while using the system. Black/brown people need to not expect change by hoping that the black/brown person in the office can change how the system works.  Elected establishment black/brown Dems are complicit in maintaining the current hegemonic system.

 ‚ÄúThey make rules for the slave and they make rules for the masters. You‚Äôre following the slave rules‚Äù ‚Äì stop following the slave rules.

author: @gk.dopeesq.6853
text: I'm interested in understanding what the people in the video define as being working or middle class because I don't think those terms are mutually exclusive.  Black and brown communities have been more economically heterogeneous in nature - obviously that's not true everywhere.

author: @Marss_8
text: FD once brought up the fanon quote that the oppressed always believe the worst of themselves and anytime I speak with folks in my working class community and family it rings in my head like a siren üò≠ it‚Äôs not hard to connect the dots that folks who believe corporal punishment on children is their right also believe we need more cops. Like my dad who has been racial profiled and pulled over a lot in my life and has called police the biggest gang around (true) will also be like these young kids are lost and rowdy, we need more police around ü´†ü´†ü´†

author: @baller0724
text:
Devin, at the end I have to disagree with on the fact that you don't "make" a politician do something or "lean" a different way AFTER you elect them. 

Giving someone power than saying "you will do what we want" has never worked...ijs about that part specifically. Maybe I'm missing something

replies.author: @Peridot-banana
replies.text: I don‚Äôt think that he was saying that he expects it to be a huge amount of leverage, just making the point that between Trump and Harris, only one of them is someone seeking re-election who the left has any hope of leverage over for the course of that term. I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs to the exclusion of putting pressure on her prior to being elected, it‚Äôs about the consequences of the election for having any leverage

author: @ladygrey4113
text: 1:00:31 what is this supposed purity test?

author: @desireeabdullah4669
text: @devin of Atlanta Thank you for your comment re: although Kamala may not be as progressive as we want, Donald Trump will give us nothing and will actually work to our detriment.  This is my sentiments exactly.  It need to be drilled into those who will otherwise not get it.  Thanks.‚ù§

author: @SpiritBringer92
text: I have a genuine question! Im Black Native and have alreary voted for Kamala via mail in, but I wanted to know if there are any good examples of democratic(current, not old republican party) presidents being pushed further left than they started?

author: @jasonv2375
text: Love the bits about unproductive talk and purity tests...I think a lot of leftists and keyboard activists have an unrealistic view of how politics works, what it takes to win, and how to stay in office once you're there (completely selling out notwithstanding).

replies.author: @taylor3950
replies.text: Yep. Some people really are advocating for a progressive dictatorship, even when the people they‚Äôre trying to help don‚Äôt agree with them. It wraps back around to paternalism sometimes. It‚Äôs so refreshing to find practical progressive people! If I drag myself into real life organizing spaces maybe I‚Äôll find more

author: @zionoas2
text: Imo ancestral tribalism is genetically blended unintentionally in the African America community... African Americans I'm saying not anyone who can recognize their culture. Our sixth sense of, I don't trust them, even ourselves, over zealousness comes from that. It's only a weakness because we cannot identity historical behaviors to historical interactions.

replies.author: @satqur
replies.text:
That's silly. Show me a single part of the world that wasn't racked with tribalism and inter-community violence for most of history. You can't, because that's human nature.

Attributing issues of gangland crime and vendettas in impoverished, underserved inner-city communities not to material conditions and systemic issues but to some sort of ancestral African tribal instinct is comical. That's genuinely some early 20th century pulp fiction sth, you sound like Robert E. Howard.

replies.author: @zionoas2
replies.text:
@satqur¬† I think you are misunderstanding my opinion. I am saying that there is tribalism everywhere. And in our modern day, a lot of it is documented or tracked. African Americans  don't all have that luxury. And we are also seeing studies of genetic trauma being able to be duplicated. An example might be the plausibility of African American habit of laughing and running as a post slave trauma. A higher probability of children displaying cultural or parental behaviors even when removed from the environment. 

So to spin back to my opinion, a reason African Americans have an issue is because their are behaviors, triggers, sixth sense that are inherited yet never brought to light this is where you carry said traits because we never kept a accurate record of you during the slave trade/parents didn't reveal historical records and died off.

author: @Dutchie5269
text: Capitalism needs to be highlighted-& taught -regardless where an African stakeholder resides the requirement to find a better form of capitalism will dampened Black face capitalism-this is not a recent problem/issue - Education of all sorts is vital; however, "educated" folks in decision making roles are very vulnerable, as long as capitalism continue to frame individual human action towards a desired lifestyle.--appreciate the conversation...

author: @who818
text: Can you guys do a panel about the one drop roll and its significance to Black culture. It confuses me that we do not like Jim Crow. The apartheid was a tragedy but yet we consider the outcome of Jim Crow and the apartheid as a success. How can you be biracial and be black?
